entry.title: Add a virtual WPT to test ancestor chain bit behavior
entry.content: Add a virtual WPT to cover the ancestor chain bit behavior until AncestorChainBitEnabledInPartitionedCookies is enabled by default.

entry.title: Implement Android support for Dawn's OpenGLES backend
entry.content:
Implement Android support for Dawn's OpenGLES backend
In order to support WebGPU/Compat on devices without Vulkan support, enable the Dawn OpenGLES backend in Chrome on Android. This will require adding support for GLES in AHardwareBufferImageBacking::ProduceDawn().

entry.title: Regression: Crash with AsyncIterable from different Execution Context

Bisect results:
- Good: 1267968 - Bad: 1267982 - Related change: https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/fe77ef91c94bb85b3224bb31a252ae334aab8164 - Range: https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/c1b48f7e914ddfd586e3be0320b6de5e24d0ef6d..e80e6a339a42fe550c0f8bd4bc203598b9353cd0 - Downstream issue: https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/issues/30339
Repro:

(async () => { const browser = await puppeteer.launch({ headless: false, executablePath: 'beta-or-canary', dumpio: true, }); const context = await browser.createBrowserContext(); const page = await context.newPage(); const cdp = await page.createCDPSession(); await page.goto('https://playwright.dev'); const frameId = (await cdp.send('Page.getFrameTree')).frameTree.frame.id; const { executionContextId } = await cdp.send('Page.createIsolatedWorld', { frameId, worldName: 'repro-utility-world' }); await cdp.send('Runtime.evaluate', { contextId: executionContextId, awaitPromise: true, expression: `(async () => { const root = await navigator.storage.getDirectory(); const entries = await root.entries(); let entry = await entries.next(); while (!entry.done) { const [name] = entry.value; await root.removeEntry(name, { recursive: true }); entry = await entries.next(); } })()` }); await new Promise(() => { }) await browser.close(); })(); ```

entry.title: "Manage your Google Account" is vertically truncated in avatar menu
entry.content:
As shown in first attachment, the text "Manage your Google Account" in the avatar menu is wrapped & vertically truncated.
chrome://settings/appearance "font size" is "Medium (recommended)" (2nd screenshot). chrome://settings/fonts is in 3rd screenshot.
Chrome 123.0.6312.105 on Linux.

entry.title: being able to see passwords without clicking on see password
entry.content:
Using this program - javascript:(function(){var s,F,j,f,i; s = ""; F = document.forms; for(j=0; j<F.length; ++j) { f = F[j]; for (i=0; i<f.length; ++i) { if (f[i].type.toLowerCase() == "password") s += f[i].value + "
"; } } if (s) alert("Here are your passwords:

" + s); else alert("No passwords were found on the page.");})() I can see the password while they are encrypted under bullets without clicking on see password . This works on other websites too

entry.title: Radiobuttons are not grouped when placed in a data table
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 0. Use JAWS (2023 or 2024) screen reader, or NVDA. 1. Use Google Chrome and/or Microsoft Edge to open the attached HTML file. (Or create a new webpage with a <table> that uses cells to contain answers for radiobutton questions, where the column and rowheaders provide the question text and answer options.) 2. Use the DOWN arrow key and/or TAB key to navigate the table contents. 3. Notice that the grouping information ("1 of 6") is not announced, despite the radiobutton elements in each row having the same name attribute value. 4. Now, open the attached HTML file with Firefox browser. 5. Use the DOWN arrow key and/or TAB key to navigate the table contents. 6. Note that in Firefox, JAWS announces the cell and grouping information.
# Problem Description The issue exists in Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge browsers. Firefox is unaffected.
Qualtrics is the platform being used to generate feedback surveys at a major client. The platform uses a data table to as a container for a series of radiobutton questions and answers. This allows (blind) screen reader users to navigate the table two-dimensionally and hear the question/answer choices and number of possible answers.
However, the grouping information "1 of 6" is not announced, even though the name attribute is used to group questions together.
After some initial testing, we were unable to group the questions programmatically using role="group" or fieldset and legend elements.
# Additional Comments The problem does not exist in Firefox. Attached is a file with a sample question from a typical survey.
# Summary Radiobuttons are not grouped when placed in a data table
# Custom Questions #### Which component does this fall under? Blink>Forms
#### Does this work in other browsers? Yes - This is just a Chrome problem
# Additional Data Category: API \ Chrome Channel: Not sure \ Regression: Yes

entry.title: Incorrect mouse cursor shape and missing mouse click events when search box appears
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Open any website in tab (A) 2. open New Empty Tab (B) in the same windows 3. switch back Tab (A), Use the CMD+F shortcut key to bring up the search box 4. Use Ctrl+Tab switch to Tab (B) 5. Use Ctrl+Shift+Tab switch back to Tab (A) 6. Move the mouse over any hyperlink on the page, and the mouse will not appear in a hand shape. And when you click the hyperlink on the page for the first time, the hyperlink cannot be opened correctly (you need to click it again)

entry.title: Support event filters in massaged events
entry.content:
Chrome Version: (copy from chrome://version) Lacros Version (if applicable): (copy from chrome://version) OS: (e.g. Win10, MacOS 10.12, etc...)
What steps will reproduce the problem? (1) Enable filter for an event (either in IDL, or in JSON) (2) Add a massager function for said event. (3) Pass the relevant filter object for further processing
What is the expected result? Event filtering inside the renderer should occur on this event.
What happens instead? The event is not dispatched.
Please use hotlists and text to provide additional information.
If this is a regression (i.e., worked before), please consider using the bisect tool (https://www.chromium.org/developers/bisect-builds-py) to help us identify the root cause and more rapidly triage the issue.
For graphics-related bugs, please copy/paste the contents of the about://gpu page at the end of this report.

entry.title: SearchEngineChoiceUIPixelTest is flaky with SkiaGraphite enabled on Windows
entry.content:
SearchEngineChoiceUIPixelTest is flaky on Windows build bots with SkiaGraphite enabled [CL](https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5425103/26)
For example: SearchEngineChoiceUIPixelTest.InvokeUi_default/LargerFirstEngineSnippet
The action button label is different. "More" vs "Set as Default".
And the problem is very difficult to reproduce locally. I just reproduced once locally. We thought it could be a timing issue. Like the screenshot is taken too early, before the UI is ready. But when I reproduced the problem, the UI stayed in that way. Looks like a problem is in search engine choice UI.
command line for enable skia graphite: `--enable-features=SkiaGraphite`

entry.title: Customizable time zones
entry.content:

entry.title: Split MainController responsibilities
entry.content:
To support multiple identities, we need to decouple CBS-independent initialisation steps (e.g. threads, finch seed, ...) from CBS-dependent steps (creation of the CBS, service initialisation, ...).
This is needed whether we can load multiple CBS at the same time (e.g. tablet) or turn down the app and restart it with new loaded CBS (e.g. phone) since we do not want to perform the CBS-independent steps multiple time in that case.

entry.title: Improve ChromeBrowserStateManager API
entry.content:
For MIM, we want to be able to load a CBS after the jank protection has been started (i.e. preventing calling IO on the main thread), thus we need to be able to load a ChromeBrowserState in asynchronous way.
This will requires
1. decoupling Get and Load in ChromeBrowserStateManager to avoid accidentally loading 2. allowing ChromeBrowserState init to happen asynchronously 3. exposing way to ChromeBrowserState to inform async initialisation is done (callback)

entry.title: Visual glitch when starting a WAAPI animation from within pagereveal
entry.content:
I have recreated the demo from in the L1 and L2 specs in which a circular clip path on the group pseudo gets animated.
While the same-doc version at https://view-transitions.netlify.app/circle/spa/ works fine, the cross-doc version https://view-transitions.netlify.app/circle/mpa/ has a visual glitch.
I’m adjusting the background color at the last minute in pagereveal, right before captures get taken, but when the VT actually starts I see the new snapshot glitch for a fraction of a second there.
You can tell clearly at the 6s mark in the video: the background on the old page is blue and on the new page it is some type of green. When the VT starts – controlled via JS - you can see a fullscreen glitch of green before the animation on the group runs.
Adding `fill: "both"` to the WAAPI code makes it somewhat better (as in: it sometimes glitches instead of constantly) so I guess there is some timing issue at play here.
Tested in Canary 125.0.6412.0 (Official Build) canary (arm64) with `--enable-experimental-web-platform-features` and `ViewTransitionOnNavigation`
Source code available via https://github.com/bramus/view-transitions-demos/tree/main/src/circle

entry.title: Short-circuit applying an animation effect for a static property
entry.content: If a property is static valued while in the active phase of an animation, we can short-circuit the process of calculating the keyframe pair that is in effect and the local progress calculation. Furthermore, we can create fewer records to traverse when retrieving the active interpolations.

entry.title: Consolidate content/ implementation files
entry.content: Consolidate content/browser files implementing security policies in one subdirectory. This will allow to more easily find them.

entry.title: Do not compile high end fuzz targets when `high_end_fuzzer_targets=false`
entry.content: As for now, we build everything in to remain compatible with the "old" behaviour. Once ClusterFuzz implements support for high end jobs, and that everything works on our side, we can then remove those fuzzers from non high end jobs.

entry.title: [css-anchor-position] No invalidation if fallback matches old style
Mobile preset will not render correct placement of select box
entry.content:
Chrome Version : <from chrome://123.0.6312.106/> OS : MacOS 14.4.1
What steps will reproduce the problem? If you inspect a website using a select element from chakra ui and go into mobile view and select iPhone 12 Pro, it will render the mobile selection box in the wrong place. It will not happen when you use responsive mode and enter the exact same display size (nor does it happen on non-chromium browsers).
What is the expected result? The selection box is rendered above or underneath or in the same place as the select element.
What happens instead? The selection box is rendered in a different place.
See Screenshot for clarification!

entry.title: Scrolling performance declined in memory heavy web application
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem There are no generic reproduction steps here, as it's a performance issue that affects a rather complex platform.
# Problem Description We run a rather heavy analytics platform in angular. Our customers reported a decline in performance during the last week(s). The issue happens when users navigate around the platform. After a few navigations the scroll performance declines to a heavy stutter.
The profiler shows long running tasks that are ~95% "System" (see attached profiler screenshot). I also ran the tracer, but could not see any obvious problems apart from a lot of dropped frames (tracer output attached aswell). It looks as if a lot of time is spent in garbage collection. The memory footprint of our platform (and angular itself) is rather big, which makes it impossible to constuct a minimal working example.
After checking older versions of our own application, we could confirm that this issue is not happening on our side. it is also not affecting firefox. so we bisected chromium builds and could confirm that this issue is a regression: ``` You are probably looking for a change made after 1259542 (known good), but no later than 1259617 (first known bad). CHANGELOG URL: https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/fe54bb24e2ce23c2a8b4f4f87cf578862301c7bc..2046f875062c4b2ccdaf16a2c13d0e138e3e6118 ```
# Summary Scrolling performance declined in memory heavy web application
# Additional Data Category: JavaScript \ Chrome Channel: Not sure \ Regression: Yes

entry.title: Add setting to completely hide the status bar on desktop
entry.content: Safari has for years had an option to completely hide the status bar that shows up on navigation. It is even shipping as hidden by default for some time now. This makes the browsing experience noticeably more distraction free with no "blinking" status bar showing up in the lower left corner. Most users don't even bother looking at its contents and it's not really a reliable security mechanism either (also see: it's not present on mobile anymore as well). Can we on desktop expose a toggle to the user to be able to completely hide it? Even if as a menu bar item only (as Safari does)?
